item.title: On the Menu for Trump in Tokyo: American Rice
item.description: Rice is a point of pride in Japan, and the choice was a break from the typical diplomatic practice of showcasing local ingredients.

item.title: Live Updates: Hurricane Melissa, Now Stronger Than Katrina, Crawls Toward Jamaica
item.description: The Category 5 storm is the most powerful in the Atlantic Ocean this year, but its slow pace could have devastating effects. The authorities in Jamaica and Cuba ordered the evacuation of tens of thousands of people.

item.title: Israel Conducts First Airstrike in West Bank in Months and Kills 3
item.description: A militant group allied with Hamas confirmed the deaths, which were part of an increase in fighting in the Palestinian territory during a surge of settler violence.

item.title: A Tidy Dutch Town Offers a Window Into a Messy Dutch Election
item.description: Two years after a shock win for the far-right Geert Wilders, the Netherlands is returning to the polls. His hometown shows the pain points of the country’s volatile politics.

item.title: Jamaica’s Beach Towns and Fishing Villages Brace for Hurricane Melissa
item.description: Stranded vacationers on the island, which depends on tourism, used their beds to block their windows in case the powerful storm shattered the glass.

item.title: Trump Bonds With Japan’s Leader Over Baseball and U.S. Beef
item.description: The president and Sanae Takaichi, the Japanese prime minister, traded compliments in Tokyo, but signaled no major breakthrough in resolving ongoing trade issues.

item.title: Sudan’s Military Withdraws From El Fasher in Darfur, Handing City to R.S.F.
item.description: Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan confirmed that Sudan’s military had retreated from El Fasher, a decisive shift in control of the country’s sprawling Darfur region.

item.title: In Photos: Trump’s Asia Trip
item.description: He has played the roles of dealmaker, peacemaker and showman, on a tour filled with pomp and circumstance.

item.title: Father-Son Bonding at 2 Miles Per Minute on Germany’s Fabled Autobahn
item.description: Late for a rock concert, dads’ rules about driving are (legally) broken as the speedometer hits 125 m.p.h. on a highway where there are no speed limits.

item.title: More Food Reaches Gaza, but It’s Still Not Enough
item.description: Aid to the devastated territory has increased since the cease-fire took effect and prices have fallen. But many trucks going into Gaza are bringing food and commercial goods to sell that most people cannot afford.

item.title: Japanese Man Admits to Assassinating Former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe
item.description: Tetsuya Yamagami, 45, is accused of assassinating Mr. Abe with a homemade gun during an election rally in 2022.

item.title: Is the U.S. Losing in Vietnam? Russia, North Korea and China Are Gaining.
item.description: U.S. allies worry that American volatility and Russian outreach and arms sales, in particular, are driving Vietnam into a new phase.

item.title: Once Again: The Pope Likes That Other Chicago Team, Not the Cubs
item.description: Although he posed with a Cubs jersey on Monday, a gift from a religious leader also from Chicago, Pope Leo is a longtime fan of the Chicago White Sox. Some people can’t seem to keep it straight.

item.title: Rebranding Immigration
item.description: India wants to send its vast work force abroad. It may have found a way around a word that stokes opposition in many countries.

item.title: Beyond Trade War, China’s Xi Looks to Press Trump on Taiwan
item.description: China’s leader wants to weaken American support for Taiwan. But first he will want clarity about President Trump’s stance toward the island.

item.title: Palestinian Leader Lays Out Succession Plan, Elevating Deputy as Apparent Heir
item.description: Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, clarified a succession plan after more than two decades in control. He said if he vacated his role, his deputy would rule for a short period until elections could be held.

item.title: Javier Milei’s Party Triumphs in Argentina Midterm Election
item.description: The result, which gives Mr. Milei enough legislative support to keep his vetoes from being overturned, showed that many voters still back the president’s libertarian experiment.

item.title: Milei’s Win in Argentina Signals Rebuke of the Past and Trump’s Impact
item.description: President Javier Milei emerged from the election with an even tighter bond with the United States and a bigger mandate to pass transformative economic plans.

item.title: Ivory Coast President Secures 4th Term in Election Without Top Opponents
item.description: President Alassane Ouattara won 89.77 percent of the vote, but critics called the elections flawed after two main challengers were barred from running.

item.title: Diphtheria, a Once Vanquished Killer of Children, Is Resurgent
item.description: A Somali hospital ward packed with gasping children shows how war, climate and mistrust of vaccines is fueling the disease’s return.

item.title: Russia Aims Drone Attacks at Civilians, a War Crime, U.N. Inquiry Says
item.description: In the city of Kherson, in southern Ukraine, small drones routinely target ordinary people by dropping hand grenades, and record video documenting their attacks, a U.N. commission reported.

item.title: Why Trump’s Asia Visit Is Consequential
item.description: President Trump has embarked on a six-day diplomatic tour of Asia, testing his role as a statesman and negotiator as he pursues a trade deal with China. Erica L. Green, the White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains what’s at stake.

item.title: The U.N.’s food agency says cutbacks forced it to send fewer meals to storm zones.
Search Underway After Crew Member Goes Overboard on Viking Cruise
item.description: The Italian Coast Guard was assisting in the search, the cruise company said. The cruise was taking passengers from Greece to Italy.

item.title: 3 Takeaways From Vietnam’s Drift Toward Russia and Away From America
item.description: The Times examined weapons sales documents from a Russian arms supplier and interviewed dozens of officials from Vietnam, the United States and other countries in the region.

item.title: What Is the ASEAN Summit, the First Event on Trump’s Tour of Asia?
item.description: President Trump is traveling to Malaysia for the event, his first destination in a nearly weeklong trip.

item.title: In Shift in Relationship With Netanyahu, Trump Says ‘I Will Decide’ What Is Right for Israel
item.description: Since an Israel-Hamas cease-fire deal came into effect, the U.S. effort to sustain it appears to have constrained Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

item.title: Paul Biya Is Declared Winner of Cameroon Election
item.description: Official election results gave him an eighth term that, if completed, will last until he is 99. Mr. Biya is one of many leaders well over 70 across Africa, the world’s youngest continent.

item.title: Britain Needs China’s Money. It Fears What Comes With It.
item.description: A botched spying case prompted accusations that the British government was soft on China, highlighting tensions between economic and national security interests.

item.title: Going Down the Junk Food Rabbit Hole
item.description: Alice Callahan, a reporter for the Well desk, explored the history of ultraprocessed foods and how they became a major threat to our health.

item.title: ICE Detains British Media Commentator Sami Hamdi
item.description: Sami Hamdi, who often speaks against Israel, was in the United States on a speaking tour. The Department of Homeland Security said his visa had been revoked.

item.title: U.S. Assessment of Israeli Shooting of Journalist Divided American Officials
item.description: A U.S. colonel has gone public with his concern that official findings about the 2022 killing of a Palestinian American reporter were soft-pedaled to appease Israel.

item.title: Japan’s New Prime Minister Has an Advantage in Winning Over Trump
item.description: As Sanae Takaichi seeks reassurance from President Trump on trade and security, she will likely play up her ties to Shinzo Abe, a mutual friend.

item.title: Saudi Arabia, Rich With Oil, Wants to Be Known as the A.I. Exporter
item.description: The kingdom is pouring money into data centers and working with U.S. and Chinese tech giants, landing its A.I. ambitions in the middle of a geopolitical tussle for tech power.

item.title: Inside Calgary’s Fight Over Fluoride in the Water
item.description: A contentious vote over the return of fluoride to Calgary’s water was supposed to settle a decades-long debate. But the battle on both sides remains as polarized as ever.

item.title: The Russia-Ukraine Energy War
item.description: Both sides are targeting energy assets to try to break the deadlock on the battlefield.

item.title: 2 U.S. Navy Aircraft Go Down in South China Sea
item.description: A helicopter and a fighter jet went down in separate incidents while operating from a U.S. aircraft carrier on Sunday, the Navy said. The crews were rescued.

item.title: Caribbean Braces for Hurricane Melissa
item.description: A fast-developing storm was expected to bring “unprecedented” amounts of rain to several countries, meteorologists said.

item.title: Trump, Long Erratic on the World Stage, Reaches a New Level
item.description: Whether because of his increasingly mercurial approach or despite it, President Trump has won some foreign policy victories in his second term. The question now is whether he can build on his record.

item.title: Trump Leans Into Showmanship on Day 1 of His Asia Trip
item.description: President Trump presided over several deals during his first day of a nearly weeklong trip. Buried in the details are Washington’s plans to contain China.

item.title: Burevestnik Nuclear Missile Tests Successful, Russia Says
item.description: Because of its power source, the Burevestnik can remain airborne far longer than other nuclear-armed missiles.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa Could Hit as One of Jamaica’s Strongest Storms Ever
item.description: Direct landfalls from big hurricanes are rare for Jamaica. Melissa could pummel the island as an “upper-end” Category 4 hurricane, forecasters said.

item.title: Sudanese Paramilitaries Claim Control of Key Army Garrison in Darfur
item.description: The Rapid Support Forces said it had seized the army headquarters in El Fasher, its last major obstacle to controlling the sprawling western region of Sudan.

item.title: Egypt Aids Search for Bodies of Dead Captives in Gaza
item.description: The assistance is part of an international effort to reinforce the fragile cease-fire between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: How Maduro Is Responding to Trump’s Pressure on Venezuela’s Economy
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro’s opponents hope a new period of economic pain will finally topple his government. He is using cryptocurrency to hold on.

item.title: A Break-In That Shook France
item.description: The robbery at the Louvre left behind more than broken glass. It battered the pride of a nation that is increasingly glum about itself and its direction.

item.title: Suspects in Louvre Jewelry Heist Arrested, French Authorities Say
item.description: Thieves stole over $100 million in jewelry from the Paris museum. It is unclear how many people were arrested, but one man was caught while trying to leave France.

item.title: 3 Years Ago It Was a Casting Agency. Now It Has $1 Billion in Drone Contracts.
item.description: Among the flood of Ukrainian defense start-ups, one stands out to both its supporters and its critics: the drone maker Fire Point.

item.title: Under Trump’s Aegis, Cambodia and Thailand Agree to Resolve Border Dispute
item.description: It remains unclear whether the two nations can achieve lasting peace, but that did not deter President Trump from brandishing himself as a peacemaker.

item.title: Trump Announces Tariff Increase on Canada Over Reagan Ad Spat
item.description: The ad, which will stop airing on Monday, used audio of a 1987 address by Ronald Reagan making a case against tariffs.

item.title: Turkey Offered to Help in Postwar Gaza. Israel Isn’t About to Say Yes.
item.description: As a guarantor of the cease-fire, Turkey is keen to play a role in Gaza’s future, seeing political and economic benefits. Israel is having none of it.

item.title: A Furniture Town Reels From Trump’s Tariffs (and Braces for More)
item.description: Malaysia’s “Furniture City,” the town of Muar, was already losing ground. Then President Trump put kitchen cabinets in his sights.

item.title: With Trump’s Asia Trip, Speculation Mounts of a Meeting With Kim Jong-un
item.description: President Trump has repeatedly said that he wants to see the North Korean leader again. Mr. Kim has indicated that he is open to the idea — but only under a strict condition.

item.title: In Trump, Families of Cambodian Troops Detained by Thailand See Hope
item.description: They are expecting President Trump will do for their loved ones what he did for the hostages held by Hamas: set in motion a plan that leads to their release.

item.title: Francisco Pinto Balsemão, 88, Dies; Portuguese Prime Minister and Press Champion
item.description: In the wake of a revolution, he helped found a leading political party and tried to conciliate warring left and right factions, although his success was limited.

item.title: Exxon Sues California Over New Climate Disclosure Laws
item.description: The oil giant said requirements that companies calculate new details about greenhouse gas emissions and climate risks violate Exxon’s free speech rights.

item.title: Judge Dismisses Most Claims Against Tate Brothers in Florida Lawsuit
item.description: Andrew Tate, an online influencer, and his brother Tristan, have been in a legal battle with a woman who accused them of harassing her after she gave testimony in Romania.

item.title: Pope Leo’s Permission for Latin Mass in St. Peter’s Gives Traditionalists Hope
item.description: Pope Francis greatly limited the use of the traditional Latin Mass, believing it sowed division. Traditionalist Catholics are hoping Pope Leo charts a different path.
